title: 112_s161
content: The "Pinnacles National Park Act" establishes the Pinnacles National Park and defines key terms such as Map, Park, Secretary, and State. The Pinnacles National Park is established in the State with the purposes of preserving ecosystems, flora and fauna, cultural history, and the California Condor recovery program. The boundaries are defined by a map available for reference. The Pinnacles National Monument is abolished and its land is incorporated into the Park. Any funds for the Monument will now be available for the Park. References to the Monument will now be considered references to the Park. The Secretary will administer the Park according to regulations. The Secretary will administer the Park in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Organic Act. They may acquire land within the Park boundaries through purchase, donation, or exchange, including the Rock Springs Ranch Tract in San Benito County, California. The Secretary will modify the Park boundaries to include acquired land and file a map with relevant committees within 120 days of enactment. Redesignation of Pinnacles Wilderness as Hain Wilderness and expansion of wilderness. The redesignation of the Pinnacles Wilderness to Hain Wilderness includes amending references in laws and documents. Additionally, approximately 2,715 acres of land are designated as wilderness and incorporated into the Hain Wilderness. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. Authorization of appropriations is mentioned to carry out the Act.
